subject: sensor: Implement sensor "ASYNC_READ_TIMEOUT"
commitMessage:
sensor: Implement sensor "ASYNC_READ_TIMEOUT"

This change will prevent sensors from blocking all other sensor reads
and D-Bus if they do not report failures quickly enough.

If "ASYNC_READ_TIMEOUT" environment variable is defined in the
sensor's config file for a key_type, the sensor read will be
asynchronous with timeout set in milliseconds.

For example for "sensor1":
ASYNC_READ_TIMEOUT_sensor1="1000"  // Timeout will be set to 1 sec

If the read times out, the sensor read will be skipped and the
sensor's functional property will be set to 'false'. Timed out futures
will be placed in a map to prevent their destructor from running and
blocking until the read completes (limitation of std::async).

Tested: This patch has been running downstream for over a year to
        solve a slow I2C sensor reads causing IPMI slowdown.

Change-Id: I3d9ed4d5c9cc87d3196fc281451834f3001d0b48
Signed-off-by: Brandon Kim <brandonkim@google.com>

Patch Set 10:

After finding out that std::async has some limitation (if the future held is destroyed, the thread will wait until it exits, which defeats the purpose of us using threads), this is a possible solution.

For any async reads, we will create a map entry to store the future (mapped to the sensor key_type). This map will be stored outside the scope of the reads to prevent the destructor from being called.

If there is no map entry, we assume this is the first read attempt for the sensor and wait. If it reads without issue, carry on and delete the map entry.
Otherwise, keep the map entry and throw an exception. If it detects a map entry on subsequent reads, we will check to see if it has finished or not (erase the map entry if it has finished) and throw an exception without any wait.

Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 10:

Tested with Kun's debug driver:

Setting the driver to sleep for 10s, I was still able to get read outs every second (2 sensors). I tried reverting the driver's sleep time to something within our time out and saw that (after ~5 second delay) the error messages disappeared.

Patch Set 25:

Thanks Lei for the comments, I've been sidetracked with some other work so I haven't been able to get around to addressing your comments.

As an aside, the rebase seemed to break this patch because of us moving towards double from long int. The casting for val is handled fine normally, but when it's in the context of std::future<>, the conversion of std::future<int64_t> (output from hwmonio::HwmonIOInterface::read) to std::future<SensorValueType> is causing issues.

Changed the std::future objects to <int64_t>.

Patch Set 36:

Have you been running with this downstream for a while now?

Patch Set 36:

> Patch Set 36:
> 
> Have you been running with this downstream for a while now?

Hi Matt. Yes, specifically this iteration https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-hwmon/+/24337/26 (pre-factoring, with rebases to keep up) has been on most of our machines running phosphor-hwmon for the past year and a half without issue. It was to specifically solve for a case where I2C sensors may hang / take too long, bringing down our IPMI daemon.

Note that if the environment variable ASYNC_READ_TIMEOUT is not set, the else statement is triggered and the read is the same as before, so the default behavior should not have changed.

It seems like unit testing read/addValue will be quite an effort (may need some refactoring) so unfortunately, didn't have the chance to incorporate it into this patch. I'll try to think of a way that this can be unit tested.

the title can be synced up with the body
Done.

Please add some motivation -- if a sensor isn't responding quickly enough, instead of blocking all other sensor reads (and dbus) skip it as a failure.  Not all sensors respond failure quickly enough -- something like that.
Thanks updated.
This doesn't match the code? Also would be good to have an example.
I updated the commit message in gerrit, then pushed a change from my local repo which overwrote the commit message. Revamped the commit message according to Patrick's suggestion.
Unfortunately, we have to make sure the same map is used. Since mainloop is the "longer living" class, it'll pass a reference to the map to this function.

Better to move this part of code into a separated function, so that it looks a bit clearer, and then better to add some test case for this function.
And I guess it could be shared with the code in sensor.cpp?
Yes, I will factor it out to sensor.cpp

This still blocks the main thread for the asyncReadTimeout.
I'm OK with this, but eventually it could be better to schedule the async read and register a callback to update the sensor value, then it does not block at all.

Agreed, this is not a true asynchronous read but I believe a step in the right direction as it no longer waits indefinitely - which could bring down IPMI if an I2C sensor is being slow for example.

I will update with a comment noting that this is not true asynchronous read.
Why do you throw on s good (but timedout) reading?

I will update the comment with better explanation. This is the case for when `valueIsValid` is false, which if you look above is the case when the sensor was previously already in the timedoutMap. This means that the sensor has already timedout (to be placed in the timedoutMap), and we're doing a 0 second wait (every 1 second poll) to see if the thread ever finished reading. If it finished reading (but past the timedout period), we will erase it from the timedout map so that we can try again on the next read cycle.

We throw because the value took too long to read, and is likely a corrupted / invalid value - better to do a "clean" read next cycle that doesn't timeout.
Better to `using xxx =` this type so that the code reads better.
Good point, will do that.
nit: if these blocks are sufficiently similar, can they be pushed into a method?
Yes, agreed. I will factor this out.
Use TimedoutMap
Thanks, missed this.
#include <map>
Done.
asyncTimeout should be a chrono type like delay
Sure, I can change this (I was just doing the conversion inside the function so that users don't have to).
Couldn't the value still be valid if it was read here? Are we assuming that stale data is bad since we don't know how old it is?

It could be valid yeah, and I don't quite remember the history of this code but I believe we didn't want to use the stale data (but maybe stale data is better than no data?) + it taking longer than timeout (timeout was usually set to something generous like 1 second), we assumed that the sensor value may have been corrupted / bad.
I'll just leave it as a design choice, since the comments outline that this is what's happening. It should be a fairly easy fix to change this behavior if we want to change it.
This const is not really needed, remove this, then you do not have to create a copy on line 295.
Good point. I was thinking of doing this but didn't want to bother changing more code - but you're right that this would optimize a copy operation.
